title: 115_s2018
content: The "American Family Act of 2017" establishes a fully refundable Child Tax Credit by eliminating the existing credit and inserting a new section 36C in the Internal Revenue Code. The "American Family Act of 2017" introduces a new Child Tax Credit, allowing a credit for qualifying children based on their age and the taxpayer's income. The "American Family Act of 2017" introduces a new Child Tax Credit based on modified adjusted gross income exceeding threshold amounts. The applicable amount is determined by marital status and income level. The Child Tax Credit under the "American Family Act of 2017" is based on marital status and income level. The applicable amount is calculated by dividing the credit amount by $20 multiplied by the total number of qualifying children. A qualifying child is defined as a dependent under 19 years of age, with exceptions for certain non-citizens. The Child Tax Credit eligibility excludes individuals who are not dependents under section 152(b)(3). Starting in 2018, the $3,000 amount in subsection (a)(1) will be adjusted for inflation annually. Taxpayers must meet identification requirements to claim the credit. The Child Tax Credit amount will be rounded to the nearest multiple of $50 if it is not already. Taxpayers must provide the name and taxpayer identification number of their qualifying child on their tax return. The taxpayer's identification number must have been issued before the due date of the return. The credit is not allowed for a taxable year less than 12 months, except in the case of the taxpayer's death. Taxpayers who improperly claimed the credit in a prior year are subject to restrictions. No credit is allowed for a taxable year less than 12 months, except in the case of the taxpayer's death. Taxpayers who improperly claimed the credit in a prior year face restrictions for a certain period after a final determination of fraud. Taxpayers denied credit due to fraud or intentional disregard of rules face restrictions for 2 years. No credit allowed for subsequent years without proving eligibility. Credit amount reduced by advance payments. The credit allowed for a taxable year is reduced by advance payments. Excess advance payments result in an increase in the tax imposed for that year. "SEC. 7527A. ADVANCE PAYMENT OF CHILD TAX CREDIT." The Secretary shall establish a program for making advance payments of the child tax credit on a monthly basis to taxpayers, with limitations on the total amount of payments made to each taxpayer during the taxable year. The program for advance payments of the child tax credit shall apply the limitation of section 36C(b) and make efforts to reduce the estimated tax imposed on the taxpayer for the taxable year. Conforming amendments are made to the Internal Revenue Code. The child tax credit program applies section 36C(b) limitation and aims to reduce taxpayer's estimated tax. Amendments are made to the Internal Revenue Code. Amendments are made to the Internal Revenue Code regarding the child tax credit program, including changes to sections 45R, 152, 501(c), 6211, and 6213. Amendments are made to the Internal Revenue Code, including changes to sections 45R, 152, 501(c), 6211, and 6213. Section 6213(g)(2) and section 1324(b) are amended to include references to section 36C. These amendments apply to taxable years starting after December 31, 2016.
